event.title: the time of its incorporation in 1977

data.event: The population of Lancaster grew from 37,000 at the time of its incorporation in 1977 to over 156,000 in 2010.
The area where Lancaster is now located, known as the Antelope Valley, was originally home to the Paiute Indians.
In Sept. 18r the Southern Pacific completed the line through the Antelope Valley, linking San Francisco and Los Angeles.

The person credited with formally developing the town is Moses Langley Wicks, who in 1884 bought property from the railroad for $2.50 per acre, mapped out a town with streets and lots, and by September was advertising 160-acre tracts of land for $6 an acre.

event.title: mapped out a town with streets and lots, and by September

data.event: The person credited with formally developing the town is Moses Langley Wicks, who in 1884 bought property from the railroad for $2.50 per acre, mapped out a town with streets and lots, and by September was advertising 160-acre tracts of land for $6 an acre.

event.title: The following year, the Lancaster News started

data.event: The following year, the Lancaster News started publication, making it the first weekly newspaper in the Antelope Valley.

event.title: 1890, Lancaster was bustling and booming, and thanks to adequate rainfall, farmers planted and sold

data.event: By 1890, Lancaster was bustling and booming, and thanks to adequate rainfall, farmers planted and sold thousands of acres of wheat and barley.
